00001 // WANNE 2 <changed some lines>
00002 #ifdef PRECOMPILEDHEADERS
00003       #include "Utils All.h"
00004 #else
00005       #include "Language Defines.h"
00006       #if defined( ENGLISH ) || defined( TAIWANESE )
00007             #include "text.h"
00008             #include "Fileman.h"
00009       #endif
00010 #endif
00011 
00012 #if defined( ENGLISH ) || defined( TAIWANESE )
00013 
00014 /*
00015  
00016 ******************************************************************************************************
00017 **                                  IMPORTANT TRANSLATION NOTES                                     **
00018 ******************************************************************************************************
00019 
00020 GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
00021 - Always be aware that foreign strings should be of equal or shorter length than the English equivalent.  
00022       I know that this is difficult to do on many occasions due to the nature of foreign languages when 
00023       compared to English.  By doing so, this will greatly reduce the amount of work on both sides.  In 
00024       most cases (but not all), JA2 interfaces were designed with just enough space to fit the English word.  
00025       The general rule is if the string is very short (less than 10 characters), then it's short because of 
00026       interface limitations.  On the other hand, full sentences commonly have little limitations for length.  
00027       Strings in between are a little dicey.
00028 - Never translate a string to appear on multiple lines.  All strings L"This is a really long string...", 
00029       must fit on a single line no matter how long the string is.  All strings start with L" and end with ",
00030 - Never remove any extra spaces in strings.  In addition, all strings containing multiple sentences only 
00031       have one space after a period, which is different than standard typing convention.  Never modify sections 
00032       of strings contain combinations of % characters.  These are special format characters and are always 
00033       used in conjunction with other characters.  For example, %s means string, and is commonly used for names,
00034       locations, items, etc.  %d is used for numbers.  %c%d is a character and a number (such as A9).  
00035       %% is how a single % character is built.  There are countless types, but strings containing these 
00036       special characters are usually commented to explain what they mean.  If it isn't commented, then 
00037       if you can't figure out the context, then feel free to ask SirTech.
00038 - Comments are always started with // Anything following these two characters on the same line are 
00039       considered to be comments.  Do not translate comments.  Comments are always applied to the following 
00040       string(s) on the next line(s), unless the comment is on the same line as a string.  
00041 - All new comments made by SirTech will use "//@@@ comment" (without the quotes) notation.  By searching 
00042       for @@@ everytime you recieve a new version, it will simplify your task and identify special instructions.
00043   Commonly, these types of comments will be used to ask you to abbreviate a string.  Please leave the 
00044       comments intact, and SirTech will remove them once the translation for that particular area is resolved.
00045 - If you have a problem or question with translating certain strings, please use "//!!! comment" 
00046       (without the quotes).  The syntax is important, and should be identical to the comments used with @@@ 
00047       symbols.  SirTech will search for !!! to look for your problems and questions.  This is a more 
00048       efficient method than detailing questions in email, so try to do this whenever possible.
00049 
00050 
00051       
00052 FAST HELP TEXT -- Explains how the syntax of fast help text works.
00053 **************
00054 
00055 1) BOLDED LETTERS
00056       The popup help text system supports special characters to specify the hot key(s) for a button.  
00057       Anytime you see a '|' symbol within the help text string, that means the following key is assigned
00058       to activate the action which is usually a button.  
00059 
00060       EX:  L"|Map Screen" 
00061 
00062       This means the 'M' is the hotkey.  In the game, when somebody hits the 'M' key, it activates that
00063       button.  When translating the text to another language, it is best to attempt to choose a word that
00064       uses 'M'.  If you can't always find a match, then the best thing to do is append the 'M' at the end
00065       of the string in this format:
00066 
00067       EX:  L"Ecran De Carte (|M)"  (this is the French translation)
00068 
00069       Other examples are used multiple times, like the Esc key  or "|E|s|c" or Space -> (|S|p|a|c|e)
00070 
00071 2) NEWLINE
00072   Any place you see a \n within the string, you are looking at another string that is part of the fast help
00073       text system.  \n notation doesn't need to be precisely placed within that string, but whereever you wish 
00074       to start a new line. 
00075 
00076       EX:  L"Clears all the mercs' positions,\nand allows you to re-enter them manually." 
00077 
00078       Would appear as:
00079 
00080                         Clears all the mercs' positions,
00081                         and allows you to re-enter them manually.
00082 
00083       NOTE:  It is important that you don't pad the characters adjacent to the \n with spaces.  If we did this
00084              in the above example, we would see
00085 
00086       WRONG WAY -- spaces before and after the \n
00087       EX:  L"Clears all the mercs' positions, \n and allows you to re-enter them manually." 
00088 
00089       Would appear as: (the second line is moved in a character)
00090             
00091                         Clears all the mercs' positions,
00092                          and allows you to re-enter them manually.
00093 
00094 
00095 @@@ NOTATION
00096 ************
00097 
00098       Throughout the text files, you'll find an assortment of comments.  Comments are used to describe the
00099       text to make translation easier, but comments don't need to be translated.  A good thing is to search for
00100       "@@@" after receiving new version of the text file, and address the special notes in this manner.  
00101 
00102 !!! NOTATION
00103 ************
00104 
00105       As described above, the "!!!" notation should be used by you to ask questions and address problems as
00106       SirTech uses the "@@@" notation.
00107 
00108 */
00109
